instructions: Present all 15 questions. Each response maps to V, A, or K. Calculate percentages for each modality to determine primary and secondary learning styles.

framing.title: Superpower Discovery
framing.intro: Let's discover {{childName}}'s learning superpowers! There are no wrong answers - we're just learning what works best for them.

visual.description: Learns best by seeing pictures, watching, and reading

auditory.description: Learns best by hearing, talking, and listening

kinesthetic.description: Learns best by doing, touching, and moving

questions.question: How does {{childName}} best remember a new word?

options.text: Seeing it written or in pictures
Hearing it said out loud
Acting it out or touching something related

questions.question: When learning something new, {{childName}} does best with...

options.text: Pictures, diagrams, or demonstrations
Spoken explanations and discussions
Hands-on practice and trying it themselves
Looking at the pictures and illustrations
Listening to the voices, sounds, and words
Touching the book, turning pages, pointing
Drawing or showing pictures
Talking, making sounds, or telling stories
Acting it out, demonstrating, or building
Colorful pictures, videos, and visual things
Songs, rhymes, funny voices, and music
Building, moving around, and touching things

questions.question: The best way for {{childName}} to learn a new letter is...

options.text: Seeing the letter with a picture (A is for Apple)
Hearing the letter sound and name
Tracing the letter with their finger
Matching, puzzles, or finding differences
Singing, rhyming, or word games
Running, jumping, or building things

questions.question: {{childName}} is most likely to get distracted by...

options.text: Things they can see (movement, colors, screens)
Things they can hear (sounds, music, voices)
The urge to move, fidget, or touch things

questions.question: When describing a favorite thing, {{childName}} focuses on...

options.text: How it looks (colors, shapes, size)
How it sounds or what it's called
How it feels or what you do with it

questions.question: When remembering a fun day, {{childName}} talks about...

options.text: What they saw and what things looked like
What people said and sounds they heard
What they did and how things felt

questions.question: When upset, {{childName}} calms down best by...

options.text: Looking at something calming or watching videos
Listening to music or hearing soothing words
Being held, deep breaths, or physical comfort
Their face lights up and they nod
Say 'Oh!' or explain it in their own words
Start doing it or want to try immediately

questions.question: When using a tablet or screen, {{childName}} prefers...

options.text: Watching videos or looking at pictures
Apps with music, sounds, or talking
Interactive games with swiping and tapping

questions.question: When thinking about something, {{childName}} tends to...

options.text: Look up or around, visualizing in their head
Talk to themselves or hum
Move around, fidget, or use their hands
Seeing a star, sticker, or visual badge
Hearing praise, cheering, or special words
High fives, hugs, or physical celebration

scoring.description: Count responses for each modality, divide by total questions, multiply by 100

interpretation.dominant: If one modality is >50%, it's the dominant style
interpretation.balanced: If all modalities are between 25-40%, the child is a balanced learner
interpretation.dual: If two modalities are >35% and one is <30%, child is a dual-modality learner

visual: Use picture books and illustrated materials
Use color coding for different concepts
Demonstrate visually before asking to try
auditory: Use songs and rhymes to teach concepts
Encourage verbal repetition of new words
Discuss stories before, during, and after reading
Use audio books and educational songs
Allow talking through problems out loud
kinesthetic: Use tactile materials (sand writing, clay letters)
Allow standing or moving while learning
Act out stories and vocabulary words
